etymology.description: 士 (upside-down ritual axe) + 呂 (two blocks of metal) + phonetic 亼 (open mouth indicating pronunciation) -> originally copper, later extended to metal and gold
etymology.interpretation: The character 金(金) (jīn, 'metal') combines semantic components depicting materials related to ritual and blocks of metal, with a phonetic element 亼 (open mouth) indicating its original pronunciation. Over time, its meaning broadened from a specific type of metal, copper, to encompass all metals, including gold.
etymology.simplification: The character 钅(釒) maintains the metal element 金(金) (jīn, 'metal'), reduced to 钅 to simplify writing.

examples.chinese: 钅在化学中代表金属(金在化學中代表金屬)。
examples.pinyin: Jīn zài huàxué zhōng dàibiǎo jīnshǔ.
examples.english: In chemistry, the symbol 钅 (金) represents metal.

examples.chinese: 工匠利用钅打造精美的器皿(工匠利用金打造精美的器皿)，展示出传统工艺(展示出傳統工藝)。
examples.pinyin: Gōngjiàng lìyòng jīn dǎzào jīngměi de qìmǐn, zhǎnshì chū chuántǒng gōngyì.
examples.english: The artisan uses metal to craft exquisite vessels, showcasing traditional craftsmanship.
